docs.abstract: Judge James Robart, who blocked the president’s immigration order, is described by those who know him as a “judge’s judge” unafraid of making unpopular rulings.
docs.snippet: Judge James Robart, who blocked the president’s immigration order, is described by those who know him as a “judge’s judge” unafraid of making unpopular rulings.
docs.lead_paragraph: The federal judge who blocked President Trump’s immigration order is described by former colleagues and acquaintances as a “mainstream” Republican who went from a career as a highly respected corporate lawyer in Seattle to an appointment by President George W. Bush to the federal bench.

headline.main: ‘So-Called’ Judge Criticized by Trump Is Known as a Mainstream Republican
headline.print_headline: Judge Denounced by Trump Is Known for Independence

docs.abstract: Since 2011, female pop stars like Beyoncé, Madonna and Katy Perry have dominated the big game’s halftime spectacle. Lady Gaga is this year’s headliner.
docs.snippet: Since 2011, female pop stars like Beyoncé, Madonna and Katy Perry have dominated the big game’s halftime spectacle. Lady Gaga is this year’s headliner.
docs.lead_paragraph: Where did all the rocker guys go? In recent years, women have almost completely taken over the most highly visible gig in American pop: the Super Bowl halftime show, 12 minutes of music beamed worldwide. It is a ratings magnet, a marketing tool, a sponsor’s flagship, a cultural event and, of course, a live performance with no second chances, to be applauded or ruthlessly dissected, virtually in real time, via every internet resource.

headline.main: Women Rule Halftime. Can Lady Gaga Make It Rock Again?
headline.print_headline: The Women Lead at the Half

docs.abstract: These new shows depict urban America as a hellscape that needs a results-oriented boor to break regulations, crack skulls and restore order.
docs.snippet: These new shows depict urban America as a hellscape that needs a results-oriented boor to break regulations, crack skulls and restore order.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Cops don’t even want to make a damn traffic stop. Afraid they’ll wind up on Anderson Cooper.”

headline.main: ‘Training Day’ and ‘A.P.B.,’ Where the Rogue Cop Rules

docs.abstract: Cultural figures talk about the continued importance of the month at a time of divisiveness over race, politics and civil rights.
docs.snippet: Cultural figures talk about the continued importance of the month at a time of divisiveness over race, politics and civil rights.
docs.lead_paragraph: As Black History Month draws to a close, we asked several cultural figures to reflect on its continued importance — especially in this moment of divisiveness over race, politics and civil rights.

headline.main: Black History Month: Pressing Forward on the Heels of Progress

docs.abstract: The city native, about to turn 90, looks back at a glorious past and wonders what his next act will be.
docs.snippet: The city native, about to turn 90, looks back at a glorious past and wonders what his next act will be.
docs.lead_paragraph: Harry Belafonte’s New York was a lot like yours and mine. He was born in Harlem, got his first singing gig through Lester Young, his first acting role in a company with Sidney Poitier and his first lessons in a class with Marlon Brando, Rod Steiger, Bea Arthur, Elaine Stritch and Tony Curtis. He met the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a Harlem church basement through Adam Clayton Powell Jr., and met W. E. B. Du Bois through Paul Robeson; his uncle Lenny, who ran a numbers racket, introduced him to the elite of Harlem’s gangsters. He took Nelson Mandela to Yankee Stadium, planned an Amos and Andy movie with Robert Altman and, at 89, he was a co-chairman of the Women’s March on Washington last month, along with Gloria Steinem, though his health kept him from the event.

headline.main: Harry Belafonte Knows a Thing or Two About New York

docs.abstract: The Fox Sports play-by-play announcer on sports and politics, his hair-transplant surgery and, sometimes, not talking at all.
docs.snippet: The Fox Sports play-by-play announcer on sports and politics, his hair-transplant surgery and, sometimes, not talking at all.
docs.lead_paragraph: I really didn’t want to ask you about being hated, but — truly — when I told people I was going to interview you, the first thing out of everyone’s mouth was “I hate that guy.” You’ve taken this reputation with some humor, but has anything ever really gotten to you? I get more frustrated than I get hurt by it. It’s like, come on, I’m just the guy in the suit telling you your team lost.

headline.main: Joe Buck Knows Why You Hate Him
headline.print_headline: Joe Buck Knows Why You Hate Him

docs.abstract: A young, shackled black man is shot to death — and the police say he killed himself. The resulting investigation has pitted the victim’s father against the most powerful man in New Iberia, La.
docs.snippet: A young, shackled black man is shot to death — and the police say he killed himself. The resulting investigation has pitted the victim’s father against the most powerful man in New Iberia, La.
docs.lead_paragraph: No one would tell The Rev. Victor White how his son died. Everyone seemed to know — but no one would tell him.

docs.abstract: The sketch comedian takes on racial politics and the “liberal elite” in his debut feature, the horror movie “Get Out.” Here, he talks about his life and work.
docs.snippet: The sketch comedian takes on racial politics and the “liberal elite” in his debut feature, the horror movie “Get Out.” Here, he talks about his life and work.
docs.lead_paragraph: No serious fan of the sketch comedy show “Key & Peele” will be surprised that Jordan Peele (the shorter half of its starring duo) is making his directorial debut with a horror film. Their acclaimed Comedy Central series may have been best known for President Obama’s “anger translator,” but it often lampooned scary movies with a specificity that could come only from a connoisseur of things that go bump in the night. (No one has made a funnier parody of “The Shining.”)

headline.main: Jordan Peele on a Truly Terrifying Monster: Racism

docs.abstract: When he got the messages, Marc Yellin wondered, “Have we come to this?”
docs.snippet: When he got the messages, Marc Yellin wondered, “Have we come to this?”
docs.lead_paragraph: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

headline.main: Hateful Threats Against a Jewish Blogger
